intro: Ulmus nemoralis, commonly known as the field elm, is a deciduous tree native to Europe and western Asia. It typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters, featuring a broad, rounded crown and rough, fissured bark. The leaves are simple, alternate, and have a serrated margin, turning yellow in autumn. It produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in early spring, followed by spherical, woody fruits. This species is often found in open woodlands and along riverbanks, preferring moist, well-drained soils.
